title: Quiz 2: Natural Family Planning & Physiology
description: Test your knowledge on fertility awareness methods, menstrual cycle physiology, and Lactational Amenorrhoea.

questions.question: In the Basal Body Temperature method, ovulation is indicated by a temperature rise of ___BLANK___ to ___BLANK___ degrees Celsius.
questions.explanation: Ovulation causes a slight rise in body temperature, typically between 0.2°C and 0.5°C.
questions.hint: It is a small fractional rise, less than 1 degree.

questions.question:
Read the description of cervical mucus below. Which phase of the menstrual cycle does this describe?

"Mucus becomes profuse, slippery, stretchy, wet, and clear like raw egg white."

richContent.content:
Mucus Characteristics:
  • Profuse
  • Slippery & Stretchy (Spinnbarkeit)
  • Clear/Raw Egg White appearance

questions.explanation: These characteristics (slippery, stretchy, clear) facilitate sperm transport and occur during the fertile phase due to high oestrogen.
questions.hint: This type of mucus helps sperm swim.

questions.question: Select ALL the criteria required for the Lactational Amenorrhoea Method (LAM) to be effective:

options.text: Baby is less than 6 months old
Mother is fully breastfeeding (85% of feeds)
Mother is supplementing with formula at night
Baby feeds on demand, day and night

questions.explanation: LAM requires full breastfeeding (day/night, no supplements), amenorrhea, and the baby being <6 months old.
questions.hint: Think about the 'Rule of 3' for LAM.

questions.question: Match the menstrual cycle phase with its key event:

pairs.right: Release of ovum 14 days before next menses

questions.hint: Connect the hormone or action to the phase name.

questions.question: Order the sequence of events in the menstrual cycle starting from Day 1:

items.text: Hormone levels fall, endometrium breaks down

questions.explanation: Cycle: Menstruation -> Proliferative (Oestrogen) -> Ovulation -> Secretory (Progesterone) -> Ischemia/Shedding.
questions.hint: Follow the cycle from bleeding to the next bleed.

questions.question: The Sympto-Thermal Method is generally more effective than using BBT alone because it combines temperature recording with mucus observation.
questions.explanation: The Sympto-Thermal Method combines BBT, mucus observation, and other signs (like breast tenderness), providing a double-check for fertility.
questions.hint: Does using two indicators provide better data than one?

questions.question: How long (in hours) can an ovum be fertilised after it is released?
questions.explanation: Once the ovum is released, it can only be fertilised within 24 hours.

questions.question: Which of the following is a DISADVANTAGE of Natural Family Planning?

options.text: It requires systematic charting and cooperation from both partners
It has severe medical side effects
It cannot be used by women with irregular cycles

questions.explanation: NFP requires high motivation, cooperation (abstinence), and diligent charting. It works for irregular cycles but is harder. It has no medical side effects.
questions.hint: Think about the effort required from the couple.

questions.question: Sperm can live in the woman's reproductive tract for up to 7 days.
questions.explanation: Sperm can live in the reproductive tract for **3 days** (72 hours), not 7 days. This is a key fact for NFP.
questions.hint: The study material specifies the survival time of sperm.

questions.question: What happens to the cervix during the 'infertile' period?

options.text: It lowers, becomes firm, and closes

questions.explanation: In the infertile phase, the cervix lowers, becomes firm, and the os closes to hinder sperm penetration.
questions.hint: The cervix acts as a gatekeeper; when infertile, the gate is closed.
